Sulfur doping and oxygen vacancy in In2O3 nanotube co-regulate intermediates of CO2 electroreduction for efficient HCOOH production and rechargeable Zn-CO2 battery Yu Li Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization Zhengrong Xu Writing – review & editing Quanxin Guo Writing – review & editing Qin Li Methodology Rui Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ Key Laboratory of Advanced Civil Engineering Materials of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai 201804, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Civil Engineering Materials of Ministry of Education School of Materials Science and Engineering Tongji University Shanghai 201804 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Civil Engineering Materials of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tongji University, Shanghai 201804, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Sulfur doping and oxygen vacancy in In2O3 nanotubes (Vo-S53-In2O3) create a conducive electronic micro-environment for *OCHO adsorption and *HCOOH desorption. Vo-S53-In2O3 can be assembled in flow cell and Zn-CO2 battery with exceptional product selectivity and stability. By manipulating the distribution of surface electrons, defect engineering enables effective control over the adsorption energy between adsorbates and active sites in the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). Herein, we report a hollow indium oxide nanotube containing both oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping (Vo-Sx-In2O3) for improved CO2-to-HCOOH electroreduction and Zn-CO2 battery. The componential synergy significantly reduces the *OCHO formation barrier to expedite protonation process and creates a favorable electronic micro-environment for *HCOOH desorption. As a result, the CO2RR performance of Vo-Sx-In2O3 outperforms Pure-In2O3 and Vo-In2O3, where Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibits a maximal HCOOH Faradaic efficiency of 92.4% at −1.2 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) in H-cell and above 92% over a wide window potential with high current density (119.1 mA cm−2 at −1.1 V vs. RHE) in flow cell. Furthermore, the rechargeable Zn-CO2 battery utilizing Vo-S53-In2O3 as cathode shows a high power density of 2.29 mW cm−2 and a long-term stability during charge–discharge cycles. This work provides a valuable perspective to elucidate co-defective catalysts in regulating the intermediates for efficient CO2RR. Keywords CO2 electroreduction Oxygen vacancy Sulfur doping In2O3 Intermediate Zn-CO2 battery 1 Introduction Utilizing renewable electricity for conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals offers a viable technological solution to mitigate greenhouse gas accumulation [1,2]. Moreover, the Zn-CO2 battery, integrating the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), enables intermittent conversion between electrical and chemical energy [3]. This device offers a secure and cost-effective method for energy conversion/storage technologies [4]. In this context, the performance of CO2RR occurring on the cathode side emerges as a prerequisite for feasible Zn-CO2 battery. Nonetheless, due to the thermodynamic stability of C = O bond (750 kJ mol−1) and the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), it is imperative to develop efficient catalysts for driving CO2RR [5,6]. Generally, activation of CO2 and subsequent adsorption of the pivotal intermediate (*OCHO, *COOH, *CHO, etc.) are paramount steps in determining the CO2RR performance [7,8]. Defective oxygen vacancy (Vo) has been found to profoundly shape the intrinsic electronic structure and the surface characteristic of catalysts, which plays a crucial role in the adsorption and activation of CO2 [9]. Concurrently, the change of local charge density induced by Vo promotes charge delocalization, facilitating the generation of vital intermediates and modulating their adsorption affinity on catalyst surface [10,11]. For instance, Cheng et al. demonstrated that rich oxygen vacancies could enhance the adsorption of *OCHO intermediates during CO2RR, resulting in an increased Faradaic efficiency (FE) of HCOOH (91.2%) compared to poor-Vo In2O3 (79.8%) [12]. However, electron traps originating from vacancy sites may be potentially occupied by *H in aqueous electrolytes, which may lead to partial suppression of charge transfer and impede the CO2RR activity [13–16]. Additional incorporation of heteroatom and construction of co-defects provide an avenue to redistribute the regional electron and further improve the charge transfer [17–19]. For example, Wang et al. found that Cu doping could effectively stabilize the adjacent oxygen vacancies in ZnO nanosheets, thus significantly weakening the *H adsorption and boosting the CO2RR performance [14]. The catalyst achieved the FE of CO exceeding 80% from −0.76 to −1.06 V, while maintaining stable current density and selectivity throughout a 10-hour electrolysis process. Zhang et al. simultaneously incorporated oxygen vacancy and nitrogen doping into the In2O3 nanosheets (Vo-N-InON nanosheets), in which the synergistic effect between vacancies and dopants promoted the activation of CO2 and decreased the reaction free energy of *OCHO formation [20]. Thus, Vo-N-InON nanosheets achieved a high HCOOH selectivity (95.1%) with a partial current density of 6.5 mA cm−2. Typically, a favorable CO2RR catalyst requires not only a robust binding strength for reactants, but also a weak energy barrier for product easily desorbing from the catalyst surface [21]. In CO2-to-CO process, a good catalyst surface should strongly bind with *COOH, but display a weak interaction with *CO for facile desorption of CO product [22,23]. Accordingly, regarding electrochemical CO2-to-HCOOH conversion process, apart from *OCHO intermediate, another important concern is the decent desorption energy of *HCOOH for the formation of final HCOOH. Therefore, proper selection of an appropriate dopant in conjunction with oxygen vacancy is expected to judiciously regulate the intermediates and thus improve the CO2RR performance. To date, transition metals (Zn, Ag, Pd, etc.) and p-block metals (In, Sn, Pb, Bi and their metal oxides, etc.) have turned out to be effective catalysts for CO2RR [24]. Among them, numerous studies have been dedicated to developing advanced In-based electrocatalysts, profiting from their environmental friendliness and minimal toxicity [25]. Particularly, In2O3 has garnered attentions due to its exceptional intrinsic activity for CO2RR and highly competitive overpotential of HER [11,26]. Furthermore, the diverse geometric and electronic structures of oxide impart inherent modifiability for performance enhancement. Hollow structures have been proven to effectively expose active sites, which is conducive to promoting CO2 adsorption and surface catalysis [27]. Meanwhile, vacancy engineering or heteroatom doping may also enable the regulation of charge distribution surrounding the active sites [28]. Considering the analogous properties of S and O atoms [29], incorporating S may reduce the electron accumulation reduced by Vo, which mitigates the trap states occupied by *H and suppresses HER. More importantly, due to the decent electronegativity and large atomic radius, S doping in synergy with O vacancy holds promise in regulating the electron distribution and optimizing the adsorption/desorption energy [30–32]. Herein, co-defective oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping (Ds) were concurrently introduced into hollow In2O3 nanotubes (Vo-S x -In2O3) by a facile solvothermal method. Sulfur doping in combination with oxygen vacancy effectively modulated the electronic structure surrounding the In sites, thus affording the robust adsorption and low reaction barrier for *OCHO intermediate. Additionally, the introduction of Ds facilitated *HCOOH desorption into the electrolyte to form HCOOH product. As a result, Vo-S x -In2O3 showed an enhanced CO2-to-HCOOH selectivity compared to Pure-In2O3 and Vo-In2O3. Especially, Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited the FEHCOOH of 92.4% at −1.2 V vs. RHE in H-cell. In the flow cell test, Vo-S53-In2O3 achieved the FE of HCOOH exceeding 92% across a wide potential window (−0.4 ∼ −1.1 V) and a large current density of 119.1 mA cm−2 at −1.1 V. The assembled rechargeable Zn-CO2 battery delivered a high HCOOH selectivity and consistent charge and discharge cycles. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation The 0.4082 g of In(NO3)3·xH2O (99.9%) was dissolved in 5 mL N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF, AR) with agitation for 0.5 h. Then, 0.2 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, 99%) was added into above solution for another 0.5 h of stirring. The mixture was transferred in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated to 100 °C for 24 h. The white product was centrifuged, washed with ethanol and water three times, and dried at 60 °C overnight. Then, the powder was calcinated at 500 °C for 2 h under air with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The residual light-yellow powders were named Pure-In2O3. The as-prepared Pure-In2O3 powders (0.055 g) were then added into 15 mL DMF containing x µmol thioacetamide (TAA, ≥ 98%) (x = 16, 53, 100 µmol). After vigorous stirring for 30 min, the mixture was transferred into a sealed autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 12 h. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol three times and dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. These samples were labeled as Vo-S16-In2O3, Vo-S53-In2O3, and Vo-S100-In2O3 correspondingly. Vo-In2O3 was obtained using the same method excluding the addition of TAA. 2.2 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired by a diffractometer (D8 ADVANCE) with Cu Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were captured on a field emission SEM (ZEISS SUPER®55). Transmission electron microscope (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) measurements were collected by Talos F200S with SUPER X. Raman spectroscopy was performed by Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out by Thermo Scientific K-Alpha + . X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of In K-edge were investigated using a synchrotron X-ray light source, in which In foil, In2O3 and In2S3 were employed as reference samples. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was performed on EMX-PLUS. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical performances for CO2RR were carried out on AUTOLAB workstation (AUT87107) with an airtight H-type electrolytic tank using 0.1 M KHCO3 as the electrolyte. CO2 flow rate was set at 30 sccm by the mass flow controller (Sevenstar, D07-7). Carbon paper coated by catalytic ink, Ag/AgCl electrode (saturated KCl) and Pt mesh were used as working electrode, reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. For the preparation of working electrode, electrocatalyst powders (10 mg) were dispersed into 980 μL ethanol and 20 μL Nafion solution (5 wt%), followed by ultrasonication 30 min to form a homogeneous ink. Then, 100 μL ink was dropped evenly on a 1 cm2 glassy carbon paper and dried in a vacuum oven. Potentials were tested against the Ag/AgCl reference electrode and then converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale according to the Eq. (1). (1) E vs . RHE = E vs . Ag / AgCl + 0.059 × pH + 0.197 V A cation exchange membrane (Nafion 117) was utilized to separate the cathodic and anodic compartment. A magnetic stirring device was placed under the cathode chamber at 450 r/min. The outlet-gas flow rate was verified by a soap-film flowmeter. Before testing, cathode electrolyte was inflated by CO2 (99.999%) for 0.5 h to achieve a CO2-saturated solution (pH ≈ 6.8). Then, the catalysts were activated through cyclic voltammogram (CV) with 100 mV s−1 from 0.4 to −1.4 V (vs. RHE) for 20 cycles to maintain the stability of following test. The scan rate for linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was set as 10 mV s−1. Chronoamperometry test was conducted at each potential for 20 min. Double layer capacitance (Cdl) was analyzed through CV measurements between −0.05 to 0.05 V (vs. RHE) at different scanning rates (20 ∼ 120 mV s−1). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted at open circuit with frequency from 0.1 Hz to 105 Hz. Flow cell measurements were investigated by a self-designed reactor, in which cathode and anode chambers were separated by Nafion 117 and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) gaskets were utilized as linking partitions to maintain air tightness. An electrolyte of 1 M KHCO3 and 1 M KOH was utilized, respectively. Catalysts loaded on gas diffusion electrode (GDE) (1 × 1 cm2 of effective area), Ag/AgCl electrode and Pt sheet were employed as working electrode, reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. During the measurement, electrolyte was circulated utilizing the peristaltic pump (Chuxi-pump, CX100) with a flow rate of 15 mL min−1. The flow rate of inlet pure CO2 maintained at 40 sccm and outlet gas flow was measured with the soap-film flowmeter. 2.4 Product analysis Gas products were quantified by gas chromatography (GC-2014C, SHIMADZU), which was equipped with the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and the flame ionization detector (FID) for online analysis. Argon was selected as carrier gas. Faradaic efficiency of gas product was calculated by the Eq. (2). (2) FE % = v vol % × V × N × F × p R × T × i total × 100 % where v vol % represents the volume concentration of gas detected by GC, V is the flow rate of gas injection, N is the number of electron transfers ( N H 2 , N co = 2 ), F , p , R and T are Faraday constant (96485 C mol−1), standard atmosphere (101.325 kPa), gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1) and room temperature (298.15 K), respectively. i total is the total current at applied potential. 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR, Bruker Avance NEO 400 MHz) was employed for quantitative measurement of liquid products. Faradaic efficiency of liquid product (HCOOH) was calculated by the Eq. (3). (3) FE % = N × F × c × V t × i total × 100 % where N , F, c , V and t represent the number of electron transfers ( N HCOOH = 2 ) , Faraday constant (96485 C mol−1), concentration of product, electrolyte volume and reaction time, respectively. i total is the total current at applied potential. 2.5 In-situ attenuated total reflection surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) In-situ electrochemical ATR-SEIRAS measurement was conducted by a Thermo Nicolet 8700 spectrometer. The Si prism of chemical deposition Au film (∼60 nm) was uniformly coated with catalyst ink, which was employed as work electrode and assembled into a spectro electrochemical cell. Ag/AgCl electrode and Pt wire served as reference and counter electrode, respectively. The spectra were collected at −0.1 V intervals by varying the working electrode potential from −0.5 to −1.4 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution. 2.6 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation The first-principles DFT was performed by the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [33]. The exchange-functional was treated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Emzerhof (PBE) [34] functional. Spin-polarizations were carried out for all calculations. The cutoff energy for the plane wave basis expansion was set to 450 eV. Convergence criterion of geometry relaxation was imposed with the force on each atom less than 0.05 eV/Å. K-points in the Brillouin zone were sampled by a 2 × 2 × 1 within Monkhorst Pack grid for structure optimization. The DFT-D3 method was introduced to consider the van der Waals interaction [35]. The self-consistent calculations apply a convergence energy threshold of 10−5 eV. A 15 Å vacuum was added along the z direction in order to avoid the interaction between periodic structures. The free energies of the CO2RR steps were calculated by the Eq. (4) [36]. (4) Δ G = Δ E DFT + Δ E ZPE - T Δ S where Δ E DFT is the DFT electronic energy difference of each step, Δ E ZPE and Δ S represent the correction of zero-point energy and the variation of entropy, which were obtained by vibration analysis, T is the temperature (T = 300 K). 2.7 Aqueous rechargeable Zn-CO2 electrochemical battery The aqueous rechargeable Zn-CO2 electrochemical battery was constructed with a double-electrolyte system separated by a bipolar membrane. 1 M KOH solution pumped with CO2 flow at a rate of 20 mL min−1 was employed as catholyte and a GDE loaded with 1 mg cm−2 catalysts was served as cathode. The 6 M KOH mixed with 0.2 M Zn(CH3COO)2 was used as anolyte and a polished Zn plate (2 × 5 cm2) was applied as the anode. All measurements were implemented on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. The current was controlled to be 5 mA in long-term galvanostatic discharge and charge tests. The Zn-CO2 battery was operated in ambient air conditions. 3 Results and discussion The synthetic pathway of Vo-S x -In2O3 (x represented the feeding amount of thioacetamide, µmol) was schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . Briefly, MIL-68 (In) precursors were prepared and subsequently subjected to air calcination to yield Pure-In2O3 [37]. Then, Pure-In2O3 underwent the solvothermal treatment to obtain Vo-In2O3, which only contained oxygen vacancy. At the same time, accompanied with the addition of thioacetamide (TAA) as the sulfur source, the identical solvothermal method was employed to prepare Vo-S x -In2O3 with synchronous oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping. MIL-68 (In) revealed a typical hexagonal rod-like morphology (Fig. S1) and Pure-In2O3 featured a hollow nanotubular structure (Fig. 2 a and b). Vo-In2O3 maintained the hollow nanotubular morphology (Fig. 2c–f) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping substantiated a homogenous distribution of In and O elements (Fig. 2g). The obtained Vo-S16-In2O3, Vo-S53-In2O3 and Vo-S100-In2O3 still exhibited the hollow nanotubular structure (Fig. 2h–j and Fig. S2). Vo-S53-In2O3 was selected as a representative sample for detailed description. It was observed that Vo-S53-In2O3 nanotube consisted of nanoparticles with a diameter around 20 nm (Fig. 2k). The interplanar crystal spacing (0.29 nm) corresponded to the representative (222) crystal plane of In2O3 (Fig. 2l and m). EDS mapping confirmed the uniform dispersion of In, O and S elements throughout Vo-S53-In2O3 (Fig. 2n and Fig. S3). Raman spectroscopy of Pure-In2O3 revealed the absence of carbon characteristic peaks, which indicated no discernible carbon layer after synthesis (Fig. S4). XRD patterns revealed that Pure-In2O3, Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S x -In2O3 exhibited the diffraction peaks at 30.62°, 35.50°, 51.04° and 60.66°, which were consistent with (222), (400), (440) and (622) planes of In2O3 (JCPDS 06–0416), respectively (Fig. 3 a). Compared to Pure-In2O3, the (222) peak of Vo-In2O3 shifted slightly towards a higher diffraction angle due to that the presence of oxygen vacancies reduced the lattice spacing. After the incorporation of S doping, the (222) peak of Vo-S x -In2O3 shifted back to a lower angle, which was derived from the subtle In2O3 lattice expansion induced by S heteroatoms with larger atomic radius. The oxygen vacancy of the above samples was distinguished through electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), which may provide finger printing information of unpaired electrons as the signal of Vo on both surface and bulk of the material (Fig. 3b) [38]. Pure-In2O3 showed no oxygen vacancy as evidenced by the absence of discernible signal peak. The emerging symmetrical signal of g = 2.003 confirmed the presence of Vo in Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S x -In2O3, whose intensity was associated with the concentration of oxygen vacancies [39,40]. Specifically, a small quantity of oxygen vacancies were observed in Vo-In2O3 as a result of lattice vibration at elevated temperature [41]. With the augmentation of TAA, the signal intensity increased from Vo-S16-In2O3 to Vo-S53-In2O3 and subsequently declined in Vo-S100-In2O3. This observation implied that partial reductive S species generated from TAA decomposition resulted in the removal of O atoms, whereas extra S atoms might substitute Vo and lead to a decrease in the concentration of Vo [20,42]. Moreover, as the feeding TAA content increased to 200 and 300 μmol, the crystalline structure of In2O3 was still observed in Vo-S200-In2O3 and Vo-S300-In2O3 instead of forming In2S3/In2O3 heterostructure (Fig. S5). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to investigate the valence state of elements and electronic properties. In full survey spectra (Fig. 3c), it clearly indicated the coexistence of In and O elements in all In2O3-based samples while additional S peak in Vo-S x -In2O3. For O 1s spectra in Fig. 3(d) of Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S x -In2O3, the peaks located at 529.7 eV, 531.4 eV and 532.5 eV were assigned to lattice oxygen, vacancy oxygen and adsorbed oxygen, respectively [12]. Regarding Pure-In2O3, in addition of lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen, a small peak near 531.5 eV might be attributed to the C–O from trace amount of residual after MIL-68 calcination in air [43]. Notably, Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited the highest Vo content, in line with the outcome from EPR results. With the increased supply of TAA, the generation of Vo and Ds weakened In–O bond and its electron richness, which consequently shifted the peak of lattice oxygen towards higher binding energy [44]. As depicted in Fig. 3(e), the deconvolution of S 2p XPS spectra unveiled distinct peaks corresponding to S 2p 3/2 (161.6 eV) and S 2p 1/2 (162.7 eV) [45,46]. With the increase of S content, more S atoms occupying the electron-rich Vo gave rise to the peaks of S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2 shifting slightly towards lower binding energy. The incremental peak intensity and broadening of S 2p suggested that TAA led to a greater number of S atoms bonding with In atoms within the In2O3 lattice. For spin–orbit coupled doublet in In 3d spectra (Fig. 3f), two peaks at 444.6 eV and 452.1 eV belonged to In 3d 5/2 and In 3d 3/2, respectively [47]. Significantly, a slight negative shift was observed from Pure-In2O3, Vo-In2O3 to Vo-S16-In2O3 and Vo-S53-In2O3, suggesting that increasing Vo caused valence electrons clustering around In atoms [11]. Nevertheless, additional sulfur doping brought about a decrease in the content of Vo, which allowed partial electrons to redistribute towards the nonmetallic atoms from In and led to a positive shift from Vo-S53-In2O3 to Vo-S100-In2O3 [48]. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was utilized for further exploration into the fine chemical surroundings. In the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra (Fig. 4 a), the In K-edge position of Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S53-In2O3 was on a low-energy side of standard In2O3, which indicated a moderate oxidation state of In spanning from 0 to + 3 [49]. Compared to Vo-In2O3, a slight shift towards lower energy was observed for Vo-S53-In2O3, demonstrating the reduction in coordination number of In–O induced by more Vo (inset in Fig. 4a). More information of local atomic structure was inspected by Fourier-transform (FT) extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). In Fig. 4(b), the peaks located at ca. 1.75 Å, 1.95 Å and 3.05 Å were ascribed to standard In–O, In–In and In–S bonds, respectively [50,51]. The lower intensity of In–O peak in Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S53-In2O3 than standard In2O3 verified the creation of oxygen vacancy [28]. Notably, the EXAFS spectra of Vo-S53-In2O3 did not exhibit In–S bond, indicating the absence of In2S3 in the crystalline structure. A minor yet strongest peak (2.21 Å and marked with red) with a bond length longer than In–O bond was visible in Vo-S53-In2O3. This observation was mainly derived from In–S scattering interactions in the first-shell coordination environment, which suggested the successful incorporation of S atoms into the In2O3 lattice [52,53]. The k3 -weighted FT-EXAFS fitting curve for In K-edge of Vo-S53-In2O3, Vo-In2O3 and standard In2O3 were displayed in Fig. 4(c and d) and Fig. S6. As seen, the inclusion of In–S path improved the fitting quality of Vo-S53-In2O3 and demonstrated the effective trapping of S atoms in Vo site to form In–S bonds. Contour plot of Wavelet transform (WT) of In K-edge EXAFS effectively visualized the distinct atomic environment (Fig. 4e–g). The intensity maximum at 5.85 Å−1 was assigned to In–O bond of Vo-S53-In2O3, which exhibited a lower value in comparison to standard In2O3 (6.21 Å−1) and Vo-In2O3 (6.13 Å−1). In–In bond (around 3 Å of the Y-axis) of these In2O3 samples gradually weakened, aligning with the consequences of R -spaces. All the aforementioned evidence collectively demonstrated that the local electronic structure and intimate electron interaction on In active sites were remarkably tuned after simultaneous incorporation of Vo and Ds. The above characterization analyses substantiated the material formation mechanism. Initially, defect-free Pure-In2O3 was synthesized by calcining MIL-68 at 500 °C in air. The following solvothermal treatment of Pure-In2O3 at elevated temperatures induced lattice vibration in In2O3, leading to a few amounts of oxygen vacancies in Vo-In2O3. The addition of TAA during solvothermal treatment generated reductive S species through TAA decomposition, which facilitated the removal of O atoms to create Vo. At the same time, partial S atoms replaced Vo to form In–S bonds. With the increasing feeding of TAA, the content of oxygen vacancies and sulfur doping enhanced simultaneously from Vo-S16-In2O3 to Vo-S53-In2O3. However, excessive addition of TAA content resulted in extra substitution of S atoms for Vo, which led to the increased Ds but reduced amount of Vo in Vo-S100-In2O3. The electrocatalytic CO2RR performances of as-prepared catalysts were first evaluated in a H-cell setup. In linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) measurement (Fig. 5 a), the current density of Pure-In2O3, Vo- In2O3, Vo-S x -In2O3 exhibited a pronounced increase in CO2-saturated electrolyte compared to Ar-saturated electrolyte, confirming certain CO2RR activity of all the In2O3-based catalysts. Vo-S53-In2O3 showed the highest current density when the potential was negative than −0.5 V (vs. RHE) among all studied samples, which indicated its optimal feasibility for CO2RR. Chronoamperometry test was recorded ranging from −0.8 to −1.4 V to evaluate the FE of products (Fig. S7). Liquid and gas products were analyzed by 1H nuclear magnetic resonance and online gas chromatography, respectively (Fig. S8). It was found that C1 (HCOOH and CO) was the main product accompanied by the side product H2. As illustrated in Fig. 5(b), Pure-In2O3 and Vo-In2O3 showcased mediocre FE of C1 products at all applied potentials. Upon further introducing S doping, CO2RR activity of Vo-S x -In2O3 was significantly improved. Notably, Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited an outstanding FE of C1 above 90% from −1.0 to −1.4 V with a maximum of 95.5% at −1.2 V. Moreover, Vo-S53-In2O3 illustrated the lowest FE of H2 within all tested potentials and achieved a remarkable FE of the dominant HCOOH product up to 92.4% at −1.2 V (Fig. S9). Partial current density of HCOOH ( j HCOOH ), CO ( j CO ) and H2 ( j H 2 ) under different potentials were plotted in Fig. 5(c) and Fig. S10. The calculated j HCOOH at −1.4 V on Vo-S53-In2O3 was 3 and 2.2 times higher than Pure-In2O3 and Vo-In2O3, respectively. Additional experiments were performed to illustrate the underlying mechanism of intrinsic catalytic activity. Since OH− adsorbed on the catalyst surface could transfer electrons onto CO2 to form the adsorbed CO2 •−, the adsorption affinity of CO2 •− is directly proportional to OH−. Hence, OH− ions are generally employed as a surrogate to estimate the adsorption strength of active CO2 •− [54–56]. In Fig. 5(d), anodic polarization curve revealed that Vo-S53-In2O3 possessed a more negative potential, signifying an intensive binding affinity with OH−. This finding supported that the immobilized CO2 •− on Vo-S53-In2O3 had an optimized stability, which was conducive to CO2 activation. In Fig. S11 and Fig. 5(e), Vo-S53-In2O3 unveiled superior availability of active sites by attaining the highest double-layer capacitances (Cdl) of 0.83 mF cm−2. The ECSA-normalized current density of Vo-S53-In2O3 was observed to be the highest value, suggesting an enhancement of intrinsic activity by Ds and Vo (Fig. S12). The smallest charge-transfer resistance ( R ct ) of Vo-S53-In2O3 was observed in Nyquist diagrams (Fig. 5f), which suggested its low interfacial impedance and fast reaction kinetics. Obviously, the CO2RR performance of Vo-S x -In2O3 consistently outperformed Pure-In2O3 and Vo-In2O3. This enhancement may come from the cooperation of Ds and Vo intensifying the charge transfer and proton coupling adjacent to In-sites. As shown in Fig. S13, FEHCOOH first increased followed by a subsequent decline with the increase of sulfur content, indicating that there is a suitable ratio between Ds and Vo for promoting the CO2RR performance [57]. The mechanism will be discussed in the following parts. The stability of Vo-S53-In2O3 and Pure-In2O3 during continuous electrolysis was further investigated. As shown in Fig. S14(a), Vo-S53-In2O3 remained a stable current density at −1.2 V (vs. RHE) and FEHCOOH illustrated a marginal decrease of 3.9% during 21-hour electrolysis. In comparison, the selectivity for Pure-In2O3 noticeably reduced after 5 h (Fig. S14b). Additionally, there was no apparent change in the LSV and morphology of Vo-S53-In2O3 after electrolysis, indicating its remarkable stability (Fig. S15a and b). A small fraction of Vo-S53-In2O3 was reduced to metallic In after the prolonged operation (Fig. S15c), which was consistent with the previously reported works [58,59]. Limited diffusion of CO2 in an aqueous solution system invariably hampers mass transmission [60]. To this end, the CO2RR performance of Vo-S53-In2O3 was evaluated using a self-designed flow cell equipped with a gas diffusion electrode (GDE) to prompt reactions happening on the tri-phase interface (Fig. 5g and Fig. S16). The electrochemical test was firstly performed in flow cell with 1 M KHCO3 as the electrolyte (Fig. S17). It was observed that j H C O O H achieved 52.8 mA cm−2 at −1.1 V vs. RHE. An alkaline electrolyte can improve the reaction kinetics of CO2RR and suppress the competing HER in flow cell [61]. Thus, 1 M KOH was also employed as the electrolyte. Vo-S53-In2O3 delivered a remarkably large current density of 119.1 mA cm−2 at −1.1 V (vs. RHE) in 1 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. S18). As shown in Fig. 5(h), the j HCOOH of Vo-S53-In2O3 increased with the applied potential and reached a maximum value of 114.0 mA cm−2 at −1.1 V. Additionally, the FEHCOOH of Vo-S53-In2O3 kept above 92% at all applied potentials (−0.4 ∼ −1.1 V) and reached 94.5% at −0.6 V. When Vo-S53-In2O3 was operated in a flow cell with a high current density (∼50 mA cm−2) at −0.7 V, the FEHCOOH exhibited a slight decline and remained above 90% after 18 h (Fig. 5i). In comparison to the previously reported In- and Sn-based catalysts, Vo-S53-In2O3 demonstrated a superior CO2RR performance both in H-cell and flow cell (Fig. S19 and Table S1). In order to further elucidate the mechanism of CO2RR, in-situ ATR-SEIRAS was employed to detect the reaction intermediates and products (Fig. S20). The potential-dependent ATR-SEIRAS spectra of Vo-S53-In2O3 were collected within the range of 1150 and 2450 cm−1 in 0.1 M KHCO3. A couple of distinct infrared bands were observed in Fig. 6 (a and b). Two peaks at 1280 and 2340 cm−1 could be ascribed to adsorbed HCO3 − and CO2 consumption, respectively [62]. These peaks gradually intensified from −0.7 V to more negative potential applied, indicating a fast equilibrium between CO2 and HCO3 − [26]. Notably, the negative peak at 1400 cm−1 was attributed to C–O–C vibration in *OCHO species, whose intensities increased from −0.8 to −1.4 V [63]. This observation suggested a favorable protonation process for HCOOH formation. The peak at 1620 cm−1 corresponding to H2O remained almost unchanged. However, the peak strength of adsorbed HCO3 − and *OCHO simultaneously intensified from −0.8 to −1.4 V, suggesting that *OCHO intermediate was produced upon the consumption of adsorbed HCO3 − group as the possible proton donor [61,64]. Additionally, no obvious *COOH intermediates of CO product was detected, which was consistent with the experimental selectivity of Vo-S53-In2O3 towards HCOOH. Therefore, the conversion of CO2 to HCOOH was proposed to involve the following steps: (i) CO2 is activated and protonated to form *OCHO; (ii) *OCHO is further hydrogenated to form *HCOOH; (iii) *HCOOH detaches from the surface of catalyst (Fig. 6c). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were further performed to explore the impact of oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping for reaction energetics of CO2RR. The models for Pure-In2O3, Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S-In2O3 were constructed in Fig. S21. Active sites on In2O3, Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S-In2O3 were designated as In, Vo–In and Vo–In–S, respectively. The adsorbed configurations of intermediates (*OCHO, *HCOOH) on interface structures were exhibited in Fig. S22. As illustrated in Fig. 6(d–f), the adsorption behavior of *OCHO in proximity to the active site was first elucidated by charge density difference. Pure-In2O3 indicated a lack of discernible electron transfer between *OCHO and active center sites [65]. Nonetheless, *OCHO upon Vo–In site and Vo–In–S site showcased significant electronic interaction, proving activity for adsorbing the intermediate [66]. Quantitatively, profiting from the S doping, *OCHO is capable of obtaining more electrons (0.695 |e|) in comparison to that of Pure-In2O3 (0.467 |e|) and Vo-In2O3 (0.685 |e|). As a consequence, the electronic structure of Vo-S-In2O3 was optimized to facilitate adsorbing *OCHO. To investigate the profound electronic properties on the catalyst’s surface, the projected density of states (PDOS) was employed (Fig. 6g). Compared to Pure-In2O3, new defect levels emerged at the Fermi level (Ef) originating from In 5p and O 2p orbitals in Vo-In2O3 [67]. S 3p orbitals exhibited an extra defect level near Ef and a more pronounced accumulation of charges was observed around valence band (VB) of Vo-S-In2O3 (Fig. 6g). These evidences substantiated Vo-S-In2O3 as the most competitive catalyst for transferring localized electrons around VB into antibonding orbitals of CO2, which facilitated charge interactions between active sites and intermediates [68,69]. In Fig. S23, the total density of states (TDOS) on Vo-S-In2O3 showed a narrower band gap energy (0.39 eV) than Pure-In2O3 (0.68 eV). It indicated an abundance of electrons in the vicinity of E f, which was conducive to optimizing the affinity of the adsorbate and reducing the reactive energy barrier [16]. The Gibbs free energy was calculated to compare the energetics of reaction on different sites (Fig. 6h). At the first step, Pure-In2O3 encountered a high barrier, whereas Vo-In2O3 and Vo-S-In2O3 exhibited a favorable downhill. This Vo-induced conversion of endothermic reaction into exothermic process promoted the generation of *OCHO. The free-energy change (△G) in the subsequent hydrogenation from *OCHO to *HCOOH on Vo-S-In2O3 (0.504 eV) was lower than that on Vo-In2O3 (0.633 eV), proving that the incorporation of Ds facilitated the formation of *HCOOH. Typically, the reaction kinetics for CO2-to-HCOOH necessitated a proper *OCHO adsorption and *HCOOH desorption. As shown in Fig. 6(i), decent adsorption of *OCHO at Vo–In site (−1.232 eV) and Vo–In–S site (−0.992 eV) demonstrated their superior activity for *OCHO formation compared to In site (1.850 eV). Meanwhile, *HCOOH onto Vo-S-In2O3 possessed more modest adsorption (−0.387 eV) than Vo-In2O3 (−0.499 eV), which avoided the severe aggregation of *HCOOH at the active sites and prompted the subsequent desorption for HCOOH formation. Conversely, the largest energy barrier for *H on Vo-S-In2O3 mightily obstructed *H occupied at the active surface and impeded HER (Fig. S24). Furthermore, the introduction of additional sulfur doping within In2O3 lattice was modeled and denoted as Vo-S2-In2O3. Excessive sulfur doping led to enhanced proton generation and decrease in the free energy of *H to intensify the competing HER, which was consistent with our experimental observation. Altogether, Vo in synergy with Ds effectively optimized the local electronic structure on the interface of Vo-S-In2O3, thereby preserving the strong activation ability of reactants while endowing the desirable product desorption performance. Fig. S25 revealed that Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited feasible oxygen evolution reduction (OER) performance, which obtained an overpotential of 349 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and kept continuous electrolysis for 18 h. Considering the exceptional CO2RR and OER performance of Vo-S53-In2O3, an aqueous Zn-CO2 electrochemical battery was assembled to evaluate the extended application potential of CO2RR (Fig. 7 a and Fig. S26). The anode electrolyte consisted of a solution of 6 M KOH and 0.2 M Zn(CH3COO)2, while the cathode electrolyte comprised a 1 M KOH solution [4,70]. The bipolar membrane effectively stabilized the different pH values of cathode and anode fluids, enabling integration of charging and discharging processes within a single device [71]. The Zn-CO2 battery powered by Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited an open-circuit voltage of 1.369 V for 90 min (Fig. S27). The discharge and charge polarization curves illustrated an increasing difference between polarization voltages with higher current densities and suggested the practical feasibility of rechargeable Zn-CO2 electrochemical battery (Fig. 7b) [72]. Fig. 7(c) presented the discharge polarization and power density of Vo-S53-In2O3, which demonstrated a high-power density of 2.29 mW cm−2 at a current density of 4.2 mA cm−2. Stable voltage plateaus for a duration of 30 min were measured under various discharge current densities (Fig. 7d). It was observed that the FEHCOOH of Vo-S53-In2O3 achieved 95.6% at 7 mA cm−2 (around 0.3 V), suggesting dominance of CO2-to-HCOOH conversion during discharge in Zn-CO2 battery. Furthermore, the galvanostatic charge–discharge curves of Vo-S53-In2O3 at 5 mA cm−2 indicated a stable voltage gap within 27 h (80 cycles), which proved the high durability of the battery (Fig. 7e). Compared with other reported catalysts (Table S2), Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited favorable product selectivity, power density and rechargeability in reversible Zn-CO2 batteries. 4 Conclusions To conclude, a hollow Vo-S x -In2O3 nanotube with simultaneous oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping was fabricated through a facile solvothermal treatment on Pure-In2O3. The cooperative sites of oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping facilitated the electron transfer and reduced the reaction barrier to accelerate *OCHO formation. Meanwhile, the incorporation of sulfur weakened the adsorption of *HCOOH blocked on catalytic sites. Acting in the manner of altered local electronic structure originating from Vo–In–S site, Vo-S53-In2O3 demonstrated the highest FEHCOOH (92.4%) at −1.2 V, surpassing defect-free Pure-In2O3 (60.8%) and oxygen vacancy-containing Vo-In2O3 (64.2%). Meanwhile, Vo-S53-In2O3 afforded a large current density (119.1 mA cm−2) at −1.1 V and an impressive FEHCOOH (over 92%) over a wide window potential in the flow cell. Furthermore, the assembled Zn-CO2 battery based on Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibited a maximum power density of 2.29 mW cm−2 and an effective rechargeability. This study may furnish novel insights into the mechanism of co-defective vacancy and doping on the modulation of CO2RR performance and their potential application in energy conversion device. coredata.dc:description: By manipulating the distribution of surface electrons, defect engineering enables effective control over the adsorption energy between adsorbates and active sites in the CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). Herein, we report a hollow indium oxide nanotube containing both oxygen vacancy and sulfur doping (Vo-Sx-In2O3) for improved CO2-to-HCOOH electroreduction and Zn-CO2 battery. The componential synergy significantly reduces the *OCHO formation barrier to expedite protonation process and creates a favorable electronic micro-environment for *HCOOH desorption. As a result, the CO2RR performance of Vo-Sx-In2O3 outperforms Pure-In2O3 and Vo-In2O3, where Vo-S53-In2O3 exhibits a maximal HCOOH Faradaic efficiency of 92.4% at −1.2 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) in H-cell and above 92% over a wide window potential with high current density (119.1 mA cm−2 at −1.1 V vs. RHE) in flow cell. Furthermore, the rechargeable Zn-CO2 battery utilizing Vo-S53-In2O3 as cathode shows a high power density of 2.29 mW cm−2 and a long-term stability during charge–discharge cycles. This work provides a valuable perspective to elucidate co-defective catalysts in regulating the intermediates for efficient CO2RR.
